reviewText: By listening to records it is sometimes difficult to believe such glorious voices ever existed and watching these artists pour their famous sounds on stage in such good picture and sound quality it is literally a dream come true.Granted, the production is old-fashioned and so is the acting but this is one of the last remains of the golden age of opera. It's impossible to name any weak link in the cast. Cappecchi's amazing singing as Melitone alone is enough to make this Forza stand out. His full sound is unbelievable. Christoff looks funny in his fake beard but his superb singing is anything but fake. Dominguez transforms the thankless role of Preziozilla into a fascinating mezzo part. Listen to those Bs! Bastiannini's rich squillo tone and rock solid high notes justify his title as one of the best baritones ever even if the cabaletta gives him a bit of a hard time.Corelli's singing was a big surprise since I had never seen him on stage before and didn't realise how effortless he sang. The impression that I had from his records was different but he just opens his mouth and leaves the diaphragm do all the work. This was his debut as Alvaro and the role suits him like a glove. Funnily he expects applause when he enters in Act I but gets nothing. The reward comes after his big scene though.As for Tebaldi, this videotaped performance helped me understand just how HUGE her voice was. I happened to watch this with a friend who is a great (but educated) fan of one of Tebaldi's famous rivals and he was blown away by the unbelievable size of Tebaldi's voice. People who've heard her live say records don't capture half of the size of her instrument but at least I feel that this DVD brought me closer to reality. From top to bottom it's like a wall of sound as someone described it. She sings piano in the back of the stage in Padre Eterno Signor and still soars above the orchestra and chorus. You can barely hear Christoff in some parts of their duet even when she sings with her back to the audience. As for vocal quality, she has my vote for the most gorgeous soprano voice. And how fortunate we are this was performed in 1958 when she was still in prime vocal state. Listen and watch that rock solid Maledizione pour out of her mouth.Technically, the black and white (but very good for it's age) picture, the fake if lovely Benoit scenes, the ugly costumes and rather old-fashioned stage presence of the singers may put some modern opera fans off but by vocal standards forget any other opera on DVD. This is Grand Italian Opera incarnate!!!

reviewText: Really a dream cast always. I think never will be a cast like this singing any opera. Tebaldi and Corelli together, at their best on DVD... unbeliable. A MUST HAVE. I have never heard nothing as Tebaldi's La Vergine degli Angelli and Pace pace mio Dio. Really an ANGEL singing. Makes you cry. The only one missing is Giulietta Simionato instead of Oralia Dominguez. Very good sound. Black and white image but that does not matter. If you have to pay US$ 100 or more for this DVD. you will think it is cheap for the value and the joy you have watching and listening to this JEWEL. Far better than the Decca recording with almost the same cast. The DVD cast is much muuch better. You will remember this if you compare. Tebadli is a godess singing. Callas and Price are like Ciderella's sisters related to Tebaldi in this DVD.
summary: AMAZING. WISH THERE WRE 7 STARS OR MORE.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If any historic live performance of a Verdi opera on DVD is a must-have, it has to be this one. Here we have four totally magnificent artists together on the stage and all in great voice.Renata Tebaldi performs even better here than on the great studio recording she did with same conductor and the same Don Carlo. It is simply thrilling to see her sing this difficult part like there is no tomorrow. I have never heard a more moving and excting Pace, pace mio Dio.Franco Corelli is incredibly exciting from the start. He suits the part like a glove and his duet with Ettore Bastianini's Don Carlo is so moving and exciting at the same time. Bastianini is his usual magnificent selv in the role. He was enormously famous in the mid '50s and watching this performance we understand why. He acts and sing with total conviction and security. His Urna fatale aria and in his confrontation with Corelli in the final act are highlights of his performance.Boris Christoff's Padre Guardiano is also a treasure to behold. He is the very embodyment of the kind, authorative leader of the Convent. I can think of ony one that depicts that level of commitment in the role, Ezio Pinza in his recording with Rosa Ponselle. Cesare Siepi is very good in the studio recording with Tebaldi and Mario Del Monaco, but we have something here that is even better.Francesco Molinari-Prandelli gives this work much care and excitement and allows Tebaldi to hold a couple of those high notes a little longer than is written to add to the excitement of the event that is taking place.The only two things I find regrettable about this performance is that the scene just following Don Carlo's arias when Don Carlo reveals who he is to Don Alvaro is cut and we just jumps to the chorous scene with the great Preziosilla of Oralia Dominguez. And the fact that the layershift is in the middle of Corelli's great aria in the beginning of Act 3 (or Act 2 as it says on the DVD).The picture isn't too good, though, but I don't expect too much from filmed live performance from 1958, but the sound is good mono. As an added attraction there is a small interview with Renata Tebaldi as a special feature. The menu system is in Italian and is pretty primitive.This one is wholeheartly recommended to anyone even remotely interested in this great opera. We won't have arists like these any more, but we have these documents to treasure their art and the time in which they performed.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am not a person who thinks that all the great singers sang in the past, and I have other recordings of this opera I enjoy for various reasons, but what happened with this perfromance is all the main roles are sung by the greatest singers of the time - you usually don't get to see so many great voices singing in one opera, and particularly in an opera that requires heavy voices like this one.  This is Tebaldi's greatest role, from what I have seen - her singing is effortless; she almost drowns Christoff out a couple times - her voice is a dream.  Plus the character seems to suit her temperament so well - she is very touching in the role.  Corelli and Bastianini are thrilling together.  Dominguez is very good.  Christoff is very good and all the other singers are good too - there is not one weak link in this video and you are not likely to hear a more perfect bunch of singers in this opera again.  The picture is black and white and a bit grainy, however the camera work is good.  The sound is adequate for the time of the recording.  I had the situation where my dvd player would not recognize the dvd a couple times, but I just turned it off and started it up again and it worked fine.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This DVD is amazing and unbelievable. It features classic live 1958 recording of Verdi's great masterpiece, "La Forza del Destino" with Tebaldi, Corelli, Bastianini, Dominguez and Christoff as the main characters, and Molinari-Pradelli at the conductor's stand. Let me start by mentioning that we, opera fans, are just fortunate that the tressure like this survived and reached us almost 50 years after this incredible performance. Although it is absolutely impossible describe in words why this DVD is so special, I'll try my best.Let me start with Renata Tebaldi. What can one say? Her singing and acting is passionate, radiant, loving, god-fearing and desperate all in one. From the very first note she sings, you realize that this will be a special night for Renata. Her voice never sounded stronger, more beautiful and more convincing. Let me mention several places: the first act duet with Alvaro, listen to her singing "Alvaro, Io tamo" and watch how emotional she is. This is amazing. Listen to her in the next scene where she simply overpowers the whole chorus and orchestra, then comes very moving aria and unbelievable duet with Padre. And at the end she sings probably the best Maledizione in her last aria (I guess Leontyne Price sings it equally superbly).For Franco Corelli this was his debut in Alvaro's role and from the very first entrance and his first line "A per sempre..." it is clear that he was more than ready to sing this role. He is so dramatic, so warm and passionate. Nothing seems to bother him vocally. His duet with Leonora in the Act I is incredible as are his duets with Don Carlo. Speaking of Don Carlo, Ettore Bastianini gives a powerfull performance. Unfortunetaly this is the only live DVD with Bastianini. It is so sad that such an amazing singer and actor passed away only at the age of 40, just when he was reaching his peak. I can not believe that the music world can not enjoy Bastianini's Rigoletto on DVD.The last but not least, I want to mention Boris Christoff in the role of Padre. His voice is supernatural. Listen his Maledizione in the second act. I have never listened to anybody singing this better. Overall, this is must have DVD for true opera lovers. You will enjoy every second of it.
summary: The best live recording you will ever find!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Yes, the master film is worn by now, almost 50 years after it was made, there's the odd bar missing because of spots damaged beyond repair, and the black and white images are rather fuzzy. Yes, the sound is  "mid-fi" (that is, less than hi-fi but not lo-fi either). Yes, the performance has all the cuts common in italian theatres until not that long ago, cuts that wouldn't be tolerated today. Yes, the staging is outdated, the cloth decors look funny and move with air currents so landscapes and walls occasionally ondulate, and costumes seem taken out of one of those anticolonial american movies that deride the redcoats. Yes, the orchestra is far from world-class and yes, Molinari-Pradelli was no De Sabata or Toscanini. BUT YOU'RE NOT LIKELY TO ENCOUNTER A PERFORMANCE OF THIS WORK LIKE THIS ONE.A cast the stuff only dreams are made of and absolutely impossible to replicate today, simply because no-one sings italian opera like that today, because no singers active today (italian or not) match the group of principals assembled for this performance, neither in style nor in tonal qualities. The comparison with Decca's August 1955 stereo recording (in spite of the date) with their then usual Rome forces is fascinating: it shares Tebaldi, Bastianini and Molinari-Pradelli with this live Naples performance, but for contractual reasons typical of the day has Del Monaco instead of Corelli, Simionato instead of Dominguez and Siepi instead of Christoff. The vastly superior stereo sound and the controlled studio conditions, however, don't compensate for the additional frisson this live performance carries with it, in spite of the also near-ideal cast assembled by Decca (whatever reservations you may have on Del Monaco notwithstanding). What you are uniquely able to witness here is a generation of top-notch italian singers in their absolute prime and in their element, giving a performance for the ages of a work that can or cannot be placed among Verdi's gallery of masterworks (the debate apparently will never end), but that after seeing and hearing it will tip anybody's view towards the yes side.Corelli was assuming the role for the first time in his distinguished carrer and at that stage of it the voice was ideally suited for it. Tebaldi was also in her prime years and Leonora di Vargas was one of her "signature" roles, much as was also the Leonora of Trovatore, Desdemona or Tosca, with a stage presence far more convincing than in the Stuttgart Tosca DVD, where she portrays a tentative character most of the time; here she is far freer of movement and projects herself, both as actress and as singer, significantly more. Bastianini's rendition of the revenge-obsessed Carlo is powerful, with a ringing tone that would be the absolute envy of many an aspiring italian baritone today. The mexican Oralia Dominguez shines as Preziosilla and Christoff, in what might well be the only testimony on film of a complete role of his, is a compasionate Guardiano (what would we give if a film or tape of his "Boris" were found!).So, this is a performance of this particularly trucculent tale of love, death, hate, revenge and racism (one of the main reasons of the Vargas' rejection of Alvaro is his Spanish South American colonies' provenance and his mulatto condition) to treasure, a marvellous document of a bygone era of italian opera singing that seems all too unlikely to return, with  limitations (outlined at the begining of this writing) that are far outweighed by its virtues. The interview with Tebaldi included as bonus material is touching.
summary: A cast the stuff dreams are of.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This live performance contains all of the visual cliches that make opera-haters laugh at this art form:  Tacky wigs, painted drops that move when anyone walks by, stilted acting.But, My God, what vocalism.  Tebaldi and Corelli are at the height of their careers, Bastianini is magnificent.  As is the supporting cast of Oralia Dominguez, Renato Capecchi, and Boris Christoff.  The Corelli, Bastianini duet, "Solenne in quest'ora" is sufficient to justify the purchase of this DVD.  Don't hesitate to buy this DVD, you'll be blown away by it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is an absolute "must have" for any opera fan. They don't do it like this anymore and it will show you just WHY Corelli, Tebaldi, Bastianini and Christoff are held in such high esteem. An important if not THE most important video document of opera in the 1950's.
summary: An Amazing Document for Opera's Golden Age
